children.name: all through a priod of time
all day/ all morning/ all week etc
time
children.definition: a time when someone does something or something happens -- use this especially to talk about something that happensmorethanonce:
examples: ▪ Do you remember that time Tim got really drunk at Sarah’s party?
▪ Play it really loud this time.

children.name: the only/same/last etc time
examples: ▪ The last time we ate meat was at Thanksgiving.
▪ The only time I’ve seen him with a girl was that party at Mike’s place.
▪ Give us a call next time you’re in town.
▪ That was around the same time that I met Linda.

children.name: the first/second/third etc time
examples: ▪ Is this the first time you’ve played pool?
▪ Sandra, that’s the third time I’ve asked you to keep quiet.
▪ Alex won the 100 metres for the fifth time in a row he won five times, and no one else won the race in between.

children.name: four/six/several etc times
examples: ▪ This is my favourite film - I’ve seen it five times.
▪ It’s silly -- I’ve met him several times, but I can never remember his name.

children.name: a number of timesformal use this to say something happened several times
examples: ▪ She’s been to Greece a number of times.
▪ I’ve heard Jessie play a number of times, and I think he’s great.

children.name: every/each time
examples: ▪ Every time I met her, she asked me about the children.

children.name: time when
examples: ▪ Do you remember the time when Dad lost the car keys?

children.name: occasion
children.definition: a time when something happens:
examples: dịp
on one/that etc occasion
▪ The witness said that on both occasions he noticed Davis because of his heavily tattooed arms.
▪ On one occasion, Anna fainted while out shopping with friends.
▪ She had met Zahid on a previous occasion.
on numerous/several occasionsuse this to emphasize that something happened many times : nhiều dịp
▪ I’ve suggested that she should move on numerous occasions, but she never takes any notice.
▪ I remember Michael sleeping in your room on several occasions and mom not knowing about it.

children.name: moment/point
children.definition: anexacttime when something happens, during a longer process or series of events:

children.name: thời điểm
examples: ▪ The play went well, apart from one embarrassing moment when I dropped a cup.
▪ At several points during the meeting, Adler threatened to walk out.
▪ My most special moment with dad was when I was announced as the winner of Junior Beauty Contest.

children.name: moment/point in time
examples: ▪ At that precise moment in time, Binh walked in.

children.name: when you ask what time it is
ask (sb) the time
children.definition: ask (somebody) the time/ask (somebody) what timeit is   to ask someone to tell you the time:
examples: ▪ She was walking home near Colbayns School when a man approached her and asked her the time.
▪ She was distracted for a moment by someone asking the time.
▪ Go and ask Dad what time it is.
▪ If you’ve got a watch, why are you asking what time it is?

children.name: what time is it?
children.definition: alsowhat’s the time?British  spoken say this to ask someone you are with to tell you the time:

children.name: ▪ ‘What time is it?’ ‘Just after four o'clock.’
examples: ▪ What’s the time? Is it after 10?

children.name: have you got the time?
children.definition: British /do you have the time? American  spoken say this to ask someone the time, when you do not know whether they have a watch:
examples: ▪ Sorry to trouble you, but do you have the time?

children.name: have the right time
examples: ▪ Does anyone have the right time here?

children.name: have the time on you British
examples: ▪ Excuse me! Have you got the time on you please?

children.name: ways of saying what time it is
o'clock
children.definition: use this when the time is exactly a particular hour:
examples: ▪ It’s 5 o'clock.
▪ It’s exactly 10 o'clock.

children.name: just before/after
children.definition: alsojustgoneBritish   use this when the time is a little before or after a particular hour:
examples: ▪ It’s just before 6.
▪ It’s just after 10 o'clock.

children.name: ▪ It’s just gone midnight. just after
to/of [US]
children.definition: use this to say that the time is a particular number of minutes before a particular hour:
examples: ▪ It’s ten to six.
▪ It doesn’t get dark until about twenty to ten.
▪ It’s a quarter of eleven.
▪ Joe, by the ten of eight you’re going upstairs and that’s only about a half hour from now.

children.name: past
children.definition: alsoafterAmerican  use this to say that the time is a particular number of minutes after a particular hour:
examples: ▪ It’s quarter past four.
▪ It’s ten after five.
▪ It’s quarter after eight, and Laurie’s showing up at nine.
▪ It’s half past two.

children.name: it’s getting on for
children.definition: British use this to say that it is almost a particular time, especially when you are guessing what time it might be:
examples: ▪ It’s getting on for five o'clock.
▪ I should think it’s getting on for ten by now.

children.name: bang/dead on
children.definition: British informal use this to say that it is exactly a particular time:

children.name: ▪ ‘What time is it?’ ‘Bang on midnight.’
examples: ▪ I make it dead on half past by my watch.
▪ We finished bang on eight, and we were back home by nine.

children.name: what hour, day etc st happens
time
children.definition: the particular minute or hour of the day when something is planned to happen, or the particular minute or hour that it happened in thepast:
examples: the time of something
▪ Could I have the times of the trains to Birmingham please?
▪ This leaflet lists the dates and times of all the concerts.
▪ The police are still trying to establish the exact time of her death.
what time?
▪ What time did you see the man leave the bus station?
▪ What time do you usually start in the mornings?
▪ What time is the news on?
departure/arrival timethe time when a train, plane, etc leaves or arrives : thời gian khởi hành / đến
▪ The departure times are posted on our website.
▪ The plane’s estimated arrival time is 19:45.
opening/closing timethe time when a shop, office etc opens or closes : giờ mở cửa, giờ đóng cửa ( bắt đầu mở, đóng )
▪ We went into a cafe and sat there until closing time.
▪ I’ve got to get this to the video store by closing time.
opening timesthe normal times when a shop is open : giờ mở cửa
▪ Check with the museum for opening times at www.musart.
co.lunchtime/dinnertime etcthe time when you have a meal
▪ Robbie! It’s suppertime!
time of year/day etc
▪ The winds are pretty strong at this time of year.
▪ There won’t be much traffic on the roads at this time of night.
by that timeafter a particular hour of the day or night has passed : trước lúc đó
▪ Well, most people had gone to bed by that time of night.
▪ She apologized for being late, but by that time I was really annoyed with her.

children.name: date
children.definition: the day, month, oryearwhen something is planned to happen, or happened:

children.name: ngày ( bao gồm ngày, tháng, năm )
examples: ▪ Do you know the date when the house was built?
▪ We still haven’t received notification of the exam date.
the date(s) of something : ngày ...
▪ Give me the dates of the American War of Independence.
▪ June 9th is the date of the European elections.

children.name: date for : ngày cho
examples: ▪ We need to arrange a date for the next meeting.
▪ A date for his release has not yet been agreed.

children.name: set a date (for something)choose a particular date : đặt , sắp xếp ngày cho
examples: ▪ Have they set a date for the wedding yet?

children.name: birth date/date of birththe date on which someone was born : ngày sinh
examples: ▪ It helps if you provide your birth date and Social Security number.
▪ Could I have your name and your date of birth please?

children.name: start datethe date when something begins, especially a job : ngày bắt đầu
examples: ▪ I later received confirmation of my new job in a letter indicating the start date.

children.name: closing datethe date when a competition, offer etc ends : ngày kết thúc
examples: ▪ The closing date for entries is 3 March 2001.

children.name: expiry dateBritish /expiration dateAmerican the date on which something can no longer be used : ngày hết hạn
examples: ▪ Key in your credit card details, including the expiration date of the card.
▪ Are you sure these yoghurts are ok? Have you checked the expiry date?

children.name: launch/release datethe date when a new product, film, etc is shown to people : ngày ra mắt, ngày phát hành
examples: ▪ ‘Snow White’ had a December release date to capture the Christmas market.

children.name: hours
children.definition: a fixed period of time in the day when a particular activity, business etc happens:

children.name: giờ
examples: ▪ I’d like to return something to your store - what are your hours?

children.name: office/opening/business hourswhen an office, shop etc is open : giờ hành chính, mở cửa, làm việc
examples: ▪ Our telephone hotline is open during regular business hours.

children.name: visiting hourswhen you can visit someone in the hospital : giờ thăm viếng
examples: ▪ Visiting hours are from 2 to 5 every day.
after hoursafter an office, shop etc is closed : sau giờ làm việc, hành chính, mở cửa ....
▪ After hours callers can leave a voicemail message.

children.name: out of hoursBritish before or after the usual business hours : ngoài giờ làm việc , hành chính
examples: ▪ What was Tom doing in the office out of hours?

children.name: hour
children.definition: a particular period orpointof time during the day or night:
examples: at this hourvery late at night or early in the morning : tại thời điểm này ( quá muộn hay sớm trong ngày )
▪ Sir, I’m sorry to bother you at this hour.at some ungodly hour informal very late or very early
▪ We had to get up at some ungodly hour to catch our train.
at all hours
▪ There’s something happening on our street at all hours of the day and night.
lunch/dinner hour
▪ I hate telemarketers who call during the dinner hour.

children.name: timing
children.definition: a word meaning the time, day, or date that something is planned to happen, used especially when you areconsideringhowsuitablethis is:
examples: thời gian ( thích hợp hay ko )
timing of
▪ The voter survey is crucial to the timing of the election.

children.name: at
children.definition: use this with hours and minutes of the day, special holidays, or thebeginningorendof a period of time:

children.name: at six o'clock/half-past four/midnight/lunchtime etc
examples: ▪ He starts work at 10, and finishes at 6:30.
▪ Would you like to go to the sandwich bar at lunchtime?
▪ I have a hospital appointment at 9.00 am.

children.name: at Christmas/Easter/New Year
examples: ▪ We get a week’s holiday at Easter.
▪ What are you doing at Christmas?

children.name: at the end/beginning/start (of something)
examples: ▪ Frank joined the navy at the beginning of the war.
▪ We get paid at the end of the week.
▪ The students all do a short test at the start of term.

children.name: on
children.definition: use this with particular days:
examples: ▪ The team holds a meeting on the first Monday of every month.
▪ I tried to catch him on the last day of term, but he’d already left.

children.name: on Monday/Tuesday night/Friday evening etc
examples: ▪ We’re going out for dinner on Friday.
▪ Are you doing anything special on Saturday night?

children.name: on August 12th/March 2nd etc
examples: ▪ She was born on May 12, 1913.
▪ The course starts on 14 October.

children.name: on my birthday/their wedding day/Valentine’s day etc
examples: ▪ Did you call dad on Father’s Day?
▪ Aren’t you coming here on Christmas Day?

children.name: on Thursdays/Fridays etcalsoon a Thursday/Friday etcBritish every Thursday, Friday etc
examples: ▪ Her husband takes her shopping on a Saturday to Asda.
▪ We always go to the pub on Fridays.

children.name: in
children.definition: use this with parts of the day, particular years, or particular months, and seasons of the year:

children.name: in the morning/afternoon/evening
examples: ▪ I’m usually too tired to cook a meal in the evening.
▪ We didn’t get to bed until 3 o'clock in the morning.

children.name: first thing in the morningvery early in the morning
examples: ▪ I want to be ready to leave first thing in the morning.

children.name: in 1892/2001 etc
examples: ▪ In 2004, the Olympic Games will be held in Athens.

children.name: in the fifties/sixties/1990s etc from 1950 to 1959, 1960 to 1969 etc
examples: ▪ He did a lot of abstract art in the sixties, but he’s moved on since then.

children.name: in January/February/the autumn etc
examples: ▪ I came to England in the summer of 1995.
▪ The series returns in the autumn.
▪ ‘How old is Philip now?’ ‘He’s four in December’.

children.name: ago
children.definition: use this to say how far back in the past something happened:
examples: trước
5 minutes/an hour/100 years etc ago
▪ Michael left the office 20 minutes ago.
▪ ‘When did you hurt your back?’ ‘About a fortnight ago.’
▪ My daughter was married just over a year ago.
a long time ago
▪ I met your father once, a long time ago.
a short time ago/a little while ago
▪ Did you see that program about genetics that was on a little while ago?
a minute/moment ago
▪ I had my keys a minute ago, and now I can’t find them.
not so long agoused to say that something was quite a short time ago
▪ We went down to see a show in London not so long ago.
how long ago?used to ask how far back in the past something happened
▪ How long ago was that, Dad?
▪ How long ago did you buy the computer?

children.name: on/at the stroke of
children.definition: atexactlya particular time and not any earlier or later:

children.name: đúng
examples: ▪ On the stroke of midnight, the British flag was lowered for the last time over Delhi.
▪ The judge entered the courtroom at the stroke of nine.
